awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Achieving efficient production of visible light from semiconductor nanocrystals in water
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is a nanocrystal-based light absorber that converts near infrared (NIR) to visible light in biologically friendly aqueous media. This project addresses unmet needs in the life sciences where the deep targeted delivery of light to tissue is needed because it is currently impossible deliver violet light deep inside living mammals without surgery or using a very intense laser that exceeds the mammalian pain threshold. This project will advance the development of a prototype system. The ability to deliver violet light non-invasively centimeters below the skin will facilitate new ways to detect oxygen (hypoxia) and create inexpensive light sources for point-of-care (POC) diagnostics. Potential commercial applications include mapping neural networks, mitigating pain, artificially controlling the circadian rhythm, alleviating depression, and imaging physiological processes in preclinical research. Apart from impact in these large and growing billion-dollar markets, this innovation will enable new directions in the diverse academic fields of neuroscience, light-sheet imaging and circadian rhythm research. 

The proposed project will establish novel methods for stabilizing hydrophobic nanocrystals and molecular antennas in water. The goals are to realize state-of-the art photon upconversion quantum yields with this hybrid platform in aqueous media, as opposed to previous records in organic solvent. Research objectives include establishing a kinetic or thermodynamic barrier that isolates the semiconductor nanocrystals and molecular emitters from their aqueous surroundings while preventing quenching by ambient oxygen. The nano- or micro-vesicles or emulsions proposed here will be stabilized by fine-tuning the relative ratios of various components and their differing solubilities. The spin-triplet excited state necessary for high photon upconversion quantum yields will be protected against undesired quenching by oxygen with chemical barriers or additives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This PFI-TT project addressed unmet needs in the life sciences where the targeted delivery of visible photons deep in tissue is needed. Methods for stabilizing hydrophobic nanocrystals and molecular antennas in water were established. By working with block copolymers with hydrophobic and hydrophilic sections, state-of-the art photon upconversion quantum yields were achieved with this hybrid platform in aqueous media, as opposed to previous work in organic solvent. The FDA approved block-copolymers have hydrophilic shells that provide solubility in water, and a hydrophobic core which isolates the semiconductor nanocrystals and molecular emitters from their aqueous surroundings while preventing quenching by ambient oxygen. This platform is expected to enable new experiments across the life sciences and facilitate the development of inexpensive fluorescence-based rapid diagnostic tests, e.g. for oxygen or point-of-care applications.

In term student training, the Research for Undergraduates (REU) supplement supported the participation of two undergraduate students contributing to this research. One of them is from an under-represented minority group in science, technology and engineering (STEM). The other is a second generation American eager for a research experience to improve his understanding of science. Both will go on to careers in science and engineering- one has been accepted into medical school. This award also supported the salary support and professional development of a female biomedical engineering graduate student who will defend her Ph.D. in a month, a female graduate student now obtaining her Ph.D. performing oncology research in the University of Utah medical school, and a female undergraduate researcher who will graduate in 2025 with a Bachelor of Science in Biology. This award resulted in two peer-reviewed publications. The first is entitled “Air-Stable Silicon Nanocrystal-Based Photon Upconversion" published in the journal Advanced Optical Materials in 2021. The second was published in the Journal of Physical Chemistry C in 2023. As part of this PFI-TT, students were able to experience research through a unique lens by ascertaining product-market fit, e.g. finding non-academic stakeholders who understand and would pay for the new technology, as well as examine different licensing routes. Attendance at trade shows under the banner of this award has exposed students to industrial and commercial needs for new biosensor technology. This PFI-TT program is invaluable in bridging the gap between academic research and real world applications.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2024
Modified by: Ming L Tang
